This short article explores the world of discount couches, assessing their advantages, potential disadvantages, and pointers for making the ideal purchase.

articles.author: Ankit Kumar
articles.description:
So I was vibe-coding my way through an LLM app when I hit a wall. You know the kind — you prompt something like “Build a Next.js app that fetches data from Supabase” and the model just… forgets everything 2 prompts later. 😩
Enter: Model Context Protocol — or MCP for short.
I stumbled on this repo while doom-scrolling GitHub, and honestly? It blew my mind. MCP is like giving your AI working memory. And not just "remember this name" memory — actual scoped, structured memory for apps, projects, and developer workflows.
At a high level:
Model Context Protocol is an open standard for managing memory, tools, and documents in AI systems. Think of it as a context API, but for LLM agents.
If you're building anything with large language models (ChatGPT, Claude, Gemini), you’ve probably hit the limi…
articles.title: What the Heck is Model Context Protocol?

articles.author: Kiran Rongali
articles.description:
In the fast-paced world of cloud infrastructure, support and operations teams play a crucial role in maintaining stability, security, and performance. Whether it's investigating a failed deployment, tracing suspicious activity, or accessing a virtual machine for emergency diagnostics — the right tools can make all the difference.
Here’s why Log Analytics, Azure Bastion, and Azure Firewall have become essential tools in every support engineer’s toolbox.
Log Analytics – The Eyes of Your Cloud
Real-World Example:
Why Support Teams Love It:
Real-time diagnostics using KQL
Custom alerts on resource health and anomalies
Unified visibility across resources
Azure Bastion – Secure VM Access Without the Risk
Real-World Example:
Why It’s Critical:
No public IPs required on VMs
No open RDP/SSH ports = reduced attack surface
Seamless browser-based access
Azure Firewall – Network Control with Visibility
Real-World Example:
Key Benefits:
Centralized rule management (inbound/outbound)
Threat Intelligence filtering (block known malicious IPs)
Deep traffic inspection and logging
Bringing It All Together
[User Issue] ─> [Log Analytics: trace logs] ─> [Bastion: inspect VM] ─>    [Firewall: verify access rules]
These tools empower support teams to:
Troubleshoot faster 
Access securely 
Respond confidently 
Final Thoughts:
Support teams are the first line of defense when systems behave unexpectedly. Equipping them with tools like Log Analytics, Bastion, and Azure Firewall ensures faster resolution, better observability, and iron-clad security.
🔧 These are not just tools — they’re your cloud safety net.
articles.title: 🔧 Why Support Teams Rely on Log Analytics, Bastion, and Firewalls in Azure

articles.author: Nathan Caracho
articles.description:
Monkey Patching Done Right: Essential Rules for Safe Runtime Modifications


Monkey patching is a runtime component override. This is useful for mocking dependencies during testing or extending features from an external library.
Let's patch the print function:
import builtins

original_print = builtins.print

def monkey_print(*args, **kwargs):
    message = ' '.join(map(str, args))
    original_print(f'🐵{message}🐵', **kwargs)

# Applying the patch
builtins.print = monkey_print
print('This is a monkey patching')  # 🐵This is a monkey patching🐵

Okay, this is a great tool for unit testing, extending a feature from that library, or fixing that midnight issue. But take it easy—using monkey patching is very dangerous if you don't follow these golden rules.
Be explicit


You should explicitly…
articles.title: Quick Tips: Monkey Patching

articles.author: Emmanuel Madehin
articles.description:
Section 1: YASM in Action: Alleviating React's Native Hook Challenges and Outshining Redux for Server State


This section delves into the practical advantages of YASM by first dissecting common difficulties encountered with standard React hook utilization for state and data management. Subsequently, it contrasts YASM's streamlined methodology with the often cumbersome nature of Redux, particularly when applied to server state management.
React's built-in hooks, such as useEffect, useState, useMemo, and useCallback, offer considerable power and flexibility to developers. However, their direct application in managing asynchronous operations, side effects, and state synchronization can introduce significant complexity and what is often termed "developer toil." This is especially true for dev…
articles.title: The Hidden Performance Cost of Manual Data Fetching in React

I believe the most difficult thing I ever had to code was my web page. Not so much the one I have now but the layout I originally intended for it. I just never seem to be able to get it the way I want it. Ever since the arrival of the smartphone, websites have had to be responsive and look good on phones but this does not go too well with the type of look I am going for which is a classic late 90s/early 2000s website with a kawaii theme. I am positive I will figure it out with time as long as I keep at it though.
What is the most difficult thing you ever had to code?
articles.title: What is the Most Difficult Thing You Ever Had to Code?

articles.author: Eastspire
articles.description:
hyperlane 是一个高性能且轻量级的 Rust HTTP 框架，设计目标是简化现代 Web 服务的开发，同时兼顾灵活性和性能表现。本文将详细介绍 hyperlane 框架的核心功能、API 设计、生命周期模型、路由支持及性能测试结果，帮助开发者快速掌握和应用该框架。
在 hyperlane 中，Context（简称 ctx）封装了请求和响应的各种信息。框架对 ctx 进行了扩展，使得调用请求和响应的子字段方法更加简洁。
例如，request 结构体原有方法 get_method()，传统调用方式是：
let method = ctx.get_request().await.get_method();

hyperlane 允许直接调用简化后的接口：
let method = ctx.get_request_method().await;

调用规则：
原 get 方法名后加子字段名称（小写，用下划线分隔），例如 get_method -> get_request_method。
原 set 方法名后同样加子字段名称，例如 set_status_code -> set_response_status_code。
此设计极大提升了代码的简洁性与可读性。
hyperlane 提供了多种请求方法宏，用于路由函数标记允许的 HTTP 方法：
支持组合多个方法，使用 #[methods(get, post)]。
支持单一方法简写，如 #[get]、#[post] 等。
默认无宏时，路由允许所有请求方法访问。
示例：
#[methods(get, post)]
async fn root_route(ctx: Context) {
    ctx.set_response_status_code(200).await;
    ctx.set_response_body("Hell…
articles.title: Hyperlane 框架详解与使用指南

Instagram isn’t just about showing off photos anymore—it’s also a place to unleash your creativity with an aesthetic feed layout. One trend that’s really popular now is the Instagram 6-grid feed—that’s 2 rows and 3 columns, which, when viewed from your profile, turns multiple images into one cool, continuous big picture.
So, if you want your feed to look awesome like influencers or professional brands, it’s super important to know the Instagram 6-grid feed size, from the grid size, templates, to how to make it. Don’t worry, here’s a complete guide to get you started. Take it easy—this is simple to follow, even for beginners!
An Instagram 6-grid feed is basically a way to display one big picture by splitting it into six smaller squares and posting them one by one. In the end, when people vi…
